hints.content:
To find the depth before the storm, we start with the $\purpleD{93}$ centimeter depth now and subtract the $\maroonD{35}$ centimeters that fell during the storm.

![](web+graphie:${☣ LOCALPATH}/images/d4b23f6d43ac6a904b6ac4a346788ed485957cd6)

$\purpleD{93}-\maroonD{35}= \blueE{\square}$

Let's subtract to find how much snow was on the ground to start.

![](web+graphie:${☣ LOCALPATH}/images/3429a25542d13900c2bc76ce6f6e507f43df6bf5)

$\purpleD{93}-\maroonD{35}= \blueE{58}$
The snow on Frosty Mountain was $\blueE{58}$ centimeters deep before the storm.

question.content:
During a winter storm, $35 \text{ cm}$ of new snow fell on Frosty Mountain.  Now the snow on the mountain is $93\text{ cm}$ deep.

**How deep was the snow on Frosty Mountain before the storm?**  

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] centimeters
